title: John Locke wasn’t both a philosopher and an historian
Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius: 480–524 ad, the last of the Romans—Platonist thinker who planned to translate Aristotle into Latin
Boethus of Sidon: end of 1st century bc, Peripatetic philosopher and commentator on Aristotle. Carneades of Cyrene: 214-129 bc, head of the sceptical Academy and its most celebrated controversialist
Chaeremon: 1st century ad, Egyptian priest and Stoic philosopher, tutor to the Emperor Nero
Flavius Sosipater Charisius: 4th century ad, Latin grammarian

note: 106-43 bc, Roman statesman, orator, and philosopher. Cleanthes: 300-230 bc, second head of the Stoic school.
title: George Choeroboscus of Byzantium: 9th century ad, churchman and grammarian. Chrysippus of Soli, in Cyprus; 280-207 bc, third head of the Stoic school
Epicurus: 341-270 bc, Athenian, founder of the philosophical school based on atomism and hedonism
Eudemus of Rhodes: floruit 320 bc, Peripatetic philosopher, pupil of Aristotle
Iamblichus of Chalcis: 250–325 ad, Platonist philosopher with a particular interest in Pythagoreanism
Isidore of Seville: early 7th century ad, bishop and encyclopaedist
Nicostratus: 2nd century ad, Athenian, Platonist philosopher, critic of Aristotle
Publius Nigidius Figulus: 1st century bc, learned Roman, friend of Cicero, who wrote on grammar and theology and magic
3rd /2nd century bc, philosopher and logician. Philodemus of Gadara: 1st century bc, Epicurean poet and philosopher, some of whose works were preserved by the lava of Vesuvius

note: John Philoponus: 6th Century ad, Christian Platonist, commentator on Aristotle. Plato: 429-347 bc, Athenian philosopher. Plotinus: 205–270 ad, innovative and influential Platonist.
Pompeius: 5th /6th century ad, Latin grammarian, commentator on Donatus.
title: Plutarch of Chaeronea: 50–120 ad, historian and essayist, Platonist philosopher
Porphyry of Tyre: 233–305 ad, polymath, pupil and editor of Plotinus

note: Probus: 4th century ad, Latin grammarian. Proclus: 410–485, Platonist philosopher, who also wrote on astronomy, physics and geometry.
title: Posidonius of Apamea: 135-50 bc, Stoic philosopher, historian, teacher of Cicero and friend of Pompey. Praxiphanes: 4th /3rd century bc, Peripatetic philosopher with an interest in grammar. Priscian: early 6th century ad, an African who taught Latin grammar in Greek Constantinople
Protagoras of Abdera: floruit 450 bc, sophist celebrated for his relativism. 532 Onomasticon Marcus Fabius Quintilianus: 30–100 ad, the most celebrated and influential of Latin rhetoricians
Quintus Remmius Palaemon: 1st century ad, the first Latin grammarian—whose works are all lost

note: Theodectes: 4th century bc; poet, orator, rhetorician.
title: Themistius: 320–390 ad, Platonist, paraphrast of Aristotle, favourite of Emperors, vicar of Bray

note: Trypho: floruit 25 ad, Greek grammarian who worked at Rome.
title: Theophrastus of Eresus: 370-285 bc; pupil, friend, and successor to Aristotle
Marcus Terentius Varro: 116–27 bc, the most learned Roman of his time

note: Themistius ad Max: Letter to Maximus; Badawi (Paris, 1987); p This page intentionally left blank General Index
